div.p: CCCC MS 137 is a fourteenth-century manuscript which contains a miscellany of theological and spiritual tracts, some containing rules for the behaviour of monks and novices, suggesting that the compilation was intended for monastic use. The book belonged to the Benedictine cathedral priory of Christ Church, Canterbury, and might be identifiable with a book transferred to Evesham Abbey in the late fourteenth century. The last item, the homily of Origen on the lament of Mary Magdalene at the tomb of Christ, was a text which Chaucer was later to translate into English.
